ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the history and politics of North African countries (mainly Morocco, Tunisia, and Algeria), from ancient times to the present.  I also got an introduction to sociology.
I feel as though I have a much better appreciation of the evolution of North Africa and issues that dominate Maghrib societies today.
I learned about the history of North Africa, political power structures, and a conception of state and non-state spaces.
How to ask sociological questions and read sociology papers regarding North Africa, particularly Morocco.
I learned a lot about the society and politics of North Africa, as the course title suggests. I also learned about the term "North Africa" itself and the ways in which it's imperfect.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: assignment styles, small group discussions, guest speakers, readings/films

Could be improved:  I wish there had been more lead-up to the final paper -- suggestions for how to go about picking a topic, guidance on what is expected, more feedback on our writing beforehand, etc.  

This is a scheduling note (which might not be relevant once classes go back to in-person), but it might have been beneficial to have recorded lectures and then reserve class time for analysis and discussion.  Sometimes we ran out of time for discussions or the lectures were rushed and we didn't get through all of the content.
This course was excellent. Professor Wyrtzen is a wonderful professor and incredibly knowledgable about North Africa. The readings were interesting and class discussions were lively.
It's a very interesting course, especially when you're taking it with a group of engaged peers. The context lectures could be a little dry though, and the reading load is heavy.

Strengths: Engaging discussions, clear expectations of workload, doable and enjoyable even over the summer!
Weaknesses: Too much of a focus on Morocco, many of the conversations were dominated by the same people

The readings were engaging, and the writing assignments were well designed to facilitate learning. The course was also quite well organized; the creation of broad "themes" for days and weeks helped me keep track of the ideas we were covering.

I don't really have many recommendations. One thing I might mention is that I was excited by Professor Wyrtzen's assertion at the beginning of the term that he loves maps, and would have loved to see even more maps and graphics related to the topics being covered.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!  Professor Wyrtzen is fantastic, and the history of North Africa is fascinating and really worth knowing more about.  I was interested in almost every reading and topic that we covered, so it was a great experience.
I would recommend this class to anyone interested in learning more about North African history through a sociological frame.
Yes, if you enjoy sociology and/or history. It's a fun course if you have time for the readings. You can learn a lot, have interesting discussions, and hear cool guest speakers.
Yes, if they are interested in North Africa, and particularly if they want to view it from a sociological perspective.

Yes! I've learned so much about a region of the world that fascinates me, and I have a much better understanding of the complicated history of the region. Anyone who's remotely interested in North Africa can get a lot out of this course.

comments: Agree
